awd_titl_txt: AF: Medium: Collaborative Research: Quantum-Secure Cryptography and Fine-Grained Quantum Query Complexity
awd_abstract_narration:
Secure Internet communication faces a real threat in the form of a new breed of computer that harnesses the laws of quantum mechanics. The technical community is currently hard at work attempting to construct such "quantum" computers. While many mysteries about these devices remain, it is certain that a large-scale quantum computer would easily break all current public-key cryptography that underpins the current Internet. In certain attack models, important examples of private-key cryptography would also be rendered insecure. This 3-institution collaborative project studies the basic theoretical issues underlying these urgent threats to the security infrastructure. It seeks to understand the cryptography-breaking power of quantum computers, concentrating on two interweaving themes: quantum security for 1) authenticating, and 2) constructing quantum-secure cryptography from new primitives.  The project activities also include course development and mentorship at the graduate and undergraduate level. The project also involves specific outreach activities intended to broaden participation in Computer Science, including establishment and development of "women in computer science" chapters, outreach to local high schools, workshops for high-school STEM teachers, and development of computer science courses for a general audience at the three partner institutions.

Authentication-proofs, for example, that an e-mail really did originate from you--is a basic and well-studied cryptographic challenge. In the setting of quantum adversaries, it is not clear how to appropriately formulate this essential notion, let alone produce specific cryptographic tools that achieve it. This project is addressing both of the challenges noted above, focusing on development of strong formulations of authentication and new cryptographic constructions that offer secure authentication. Finding "hidden" algebraic structures--like the fact that two lists of numbers are merely cyclic shifts of each other--is an emblematic theme in the study of the computing power of quantum computers. Certain variants of this problem have resisted decades of concerted effort by the quantum algorithms community, and appear to be quite difficult. This project studies applications of these problems to constructing new private-key cryptographic tools with quantum security guarantees.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Computational devices that harness quantum mechanics could perform certain tasks more efficiently than familiar classical computing devices. Chief among these tasks (for which we believe quantum computers can outpace classical computers) are the very algebraic problems that underly most currently deployed cryptography. In particular, when scalable error-free quantum computers are finally built, they will "break" most deployed cryptographic infrastructure. This has led to a concerted effort to develop alternative cryptographic algorithms that can be run on today's "classical" hardware but withstand quantum attacks.

This effort requires reworking the foundations of traditional cryptography from the "bottom up," in the sense that it requires articulation of new definitions of security that reflect the power of quantum adversaries and construction of specific cryptosystems that achieve these new definitions of security. In some cases, there has been a natural path forward, which is to say that it was clear how to generalize the existing cryptographic definitions (and constructions) to reflect the case of quantum attacks. In other important cases, even the formulation of meaningful security definitions has been delicate; perhaps the most notable example of this has been digital signatures and message authentication schemes where a satisfactory framework has been a long-standing open question. This project has focused on development of new security definitions for various cryptographic primitives of interest--including these particular challenges--and design of algorithms that achieve these definitions.

In more detail, the project has developed a new definition for the notion of "unpredictability" of classical functions by a quantum algorithm; this is a critical aspect of the security of digital signature schemes. This new definition is supported by several constructions that instantiate it and, furthermore, demonstration that many standard constructions that intuitively rely on unpredictability indeed retain their properties when this definition is adopted (as one might hope). The project has also yielded new techniques for efficiently simulating various quantum mechanical states and transformations; these new exact simulations are important for fleshing out the basic landscape of computational quantum information theory and for understanding the security of related cryptographic constructions. Finally, the project has developed new definitions and instantiations of verifiable random functions and fuzzy extractors, which are important for consensus algorithms and biometric authentication.

Finally, the project has trained several graduate students in quantum information theory and quantum computing, developed new courses at both the undergraduate and graduate level, and supported standardization efforts for verifiable random functions.
